section.name: CLINICAL: PRIMARY CARE OF THE MIDDLE AGED AND OLDER ADULT

comments:
Management and evaluation of primary care problems of middle-aged and older adults in a variety of ambulatory and occupational settings. Opportunity to implement the role of the nurse practitioner with middle-aged and older adults and their families in the community. Interdisciplinary experiences will be pursued & collaborative practice emphasized. Students are expected to assess and begin to manage common chronic health problems in consultation with the appropriate provider of care. The initiation of health promotion & health maintenance activities with individuals and groups is stressed. Includes 16 hours a week of clinical experience with a preceptor.

	Students described the workload for this course as “demanding” and “rigorous.” While some found it to be too much busywork, others stated that the case studies were helpful and applicable to the clinical portion, which received overwhelmingly positive feedback.

	Reactions to the instruction format were mixed. One student commented that the seminar groups are a great way to learn, while another complained about the grading inconsistency that resulted from this division. 

	This course is required as part of the family health nurse practitioner program. NURS 657 is a prerequisite and NURS 646 is a corequisite.

section.name: CLINICAL: PRIMARY CARE OF THE MIDDLE AGED AND OLDER ADULT

comments:
This course focuses on management and evaluation of primary care problems of middle-aged and older adults in a variety of ambulatory and occupational settings. It includes the opportunity to implement the role of the nurse practitioner with middle-aged and older adults and their families in the community.  Interdisciplinary experiences will be pursued & collaborative practice is emphasized. Students are expected to assess and begin to manage common chronic health problems in consultation with the appropriate provider of care. The initiation of health promotion & health maintenance activities with individuals and groups is stressed. This class includes 16 hours a week of clinical experience with a preceptor.
	This course centers heavily on active student involvement in group discussions and clinical exercises. Case studies are assigned twice a week and require synthesis across lecture and clinical materials. The clinical component of the course was described as a great learning opportunity and students considered the variety of sites a “wonderful balance.” 
	Students did not comment on the professor for this course, Dr. Treston. However, students did comment on the clinical instructors and their role. In particular, student response to Professors Katzenbach and Bryan were overwhelmingly positive. Students appreciated the flexibility of the instructors and found them to be extremely “encouraging” in the clinical setting and in regards to the difficult course work. 
	Many students emphasized the time intensive nature of the case studies assigned each week. These studies were described as requiring as many as 8-12 hours to complete, making the class very “stressful” and “time consuming.” Beyond the demanding classwork, students saw the grading as relatively “inconsistent” and often “harsh,” adding an additional level of difficulty to the course. However, despite the challenge presented by the course, students found it worthwhile. This is an upper level course, which requires not only the prerequisite of NURS 657, but also a corequisite of NURS 646.

section.name: CLINICAL: PRIMARY CARE OF THE MIDDLE AGED AND OLDER ADULT

comments:
Management and evaluation of primary care problems of middle-aged and older adults in a variety of ambulatory and occupational settings.  Opportunity to implement the role of the nurse practitioner with middle-aged and older adults and their families in the community.  Interdisciplinary experiences will be pursued & collaborative practice emphasized.  Students are expected to assess and begin to manage common chronic health problems in consultation with the appropriate provider of care. The initiation of health promotion & health maintenance activities with individuals and groups is stressed.  Includes 16 hours a week of clinical experience with a preceptor.
The majority of students felt that this class was overflowing with information, sometimes too much information, but that the information was useful and rewarding.  Most students agreed that if they put in the time to study the class was helpful and even enjoyable. 
There was some discrepancy in grading between Professor Campbell and the seminar leaders.  Quite a few students were confused about the amount of work that was expected of them because of these grading differences.
The amount of work in this class is substantial and “amazingly consuming,” but students felt it was valuable and necessary.  The assigned coursework and cases effectively prepared students for their clinicals each week.  Prerequisite: NURS 657.  Corequisite: NURS 646.
